article.title: Effects of short-range correlations on nuclear symmetry energy within a modified Gogny-Hartree-Fock energy density functional approach

choices: The density dependence of nuclear symmetry energy using different parameter sets.
The effect of temperature on nuclear symmetry energy.
The comparison of different theoretical models for predicting nuclear symmetry energy.
The impact of the SRC on the binding energy of heavy nuclei.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which parameter set predicts the softest symmetry energy at supra-saturation densities?
choices: FFG
HMT-SCGF
HMT-exp
All three sets predict the same softness

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the shaded areas labeled "HIC" and "IAS" represent?
choices: Theoretical predictions of the symmetry energy from different models.
Constraints on the symmetry energy from analyzing heavy-ion collisions and isobaric analog states.
The uncertainty in the experimental measurement of nuclear symmetry energy.
The range of densities where the SRC effects are most prominent.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main conclusion drawn from the behavior of the symmetry energy curves in Figure 1?
choices: The SRC has a negligible impact on the nuclear symmetry energy.
The inclusion of SRC leads to a stiffer symmetry energy at both sub-saturation and supra-saturation densities.
The HMT-exp parameter set, which incorporates the largest experimentally constrained HMT, predicts the least stiff symmetry energy.
The uncertainty in the A parameter has a more significant effect on the symmetry energy than the inclusion of SRC.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the function n<sub>τ</sub>(ρ, δ) in Formula (1) represent?
choices: The binding energy per nucleon in asymmetric nuclear matter.
The single-nucleon momentum distribution function in cold asymmetric nuclear matter.
The isospin asymmetry of the nuclear matter.
The Fermi momentum of the nucleons.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the parameters A<sub>j</sub>, C<sub>j,</sub> and ξ<sub>j</sub> in Formula (1) characterize?
choices: The strength, range, and density dependence of the nuclear force.
The isospin dependence of the nucleon effective mass.
The shape and magnitude of the high-momentum tail in the momentum distribution.
The contribution of three-body forces to the nuclear equation of state.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the high-momentum cut-off parameter ø<sub>j</sub>?
choices: It determines the maximum density at which the model is applicable.
It represents the momentum above which the SRC effects become negligible.
It controls the strength of the tensor force in the nuclear interaction.
It accounts for the finite size of the nucleus.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following statements is true about the isospin dependence of the parameters A<sub>j</sub>, C<sub>j</sub>, and ξ<sub>j</sub>?
choices: They are assumed to be independent of the isospin asymmetry.
They are linearly dependent on the isospin asymmetry based on microscopic many-body theory predictions.
They have a quadratic dependence on the isospin asymmetry.
Their isospin dependence is not well-constrained by either theory or experiment.
